head.citation-title: High temperature performance polymer electrolyte membranes
head.abstracts: Proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) and direct methanol fuel cell (DMFC) require high operating temperature to enhance proton transfer mechanism without fuel crossover, and bearing the heat generated during the operation. The present review focuses on the development of high temperature resistance polymer electrolyte membranes (PEM) which function in water retention ability, enhancing reaction kinetics, and reducing electrode CO poisoning. Hydrous membranes which rely on the water clusters in the membrane to transfer proton can be stabilized to 80-100 °C with the conductivity 10-1-10-2 S/cm when the polymers are sulfonated modified aromatics or organic-inorganic hybridized composites. Anhydrous membranes compromise the conductivity based on the proton movement under resonance structure of heterocycles, and hence can be applied in water free system. Several types of membranes with heterocyclic compounds, especially imidazoles and benzimidazoles, prepared by mixing with acids, incorporating with other thermally stable polymers, copolymerizing with other polymers (such as poly(4-vinylphosphonic aicd-co- 4-vinylimidazole), poly(4,5-vinylimidazole-co-acrylic acid)), and conjugating at polymer side chains (such as benzimidazole grafted polydimethylsiloxane, multi-benzimidazole functionalized branched polyethylenimine), are reported, and in the successful cases, the conductivities are as high as 10-2-10-5 S/cm at the temperature above 120 °C. A series of benzimidazole model compounds lead us to an understanding that proton transfer mechanism is under synergistic effects of hydrogen bond network and molecular mobility. Apart from proton conductivity, other important parameters of PEM are water uptake and swelling, gas or methanol permeability, ion exchange capacity, and single cell performance. © 2013 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.

coredata.dc:description: Proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) and direct methanol fuel cell (DMFC) require high operating temperature to enhance proton transfer mechanism without fuel crossover, and bearing the heat generated during the operation. The present review focuses on the development of high temperature resistance polymer electrolyte membranes (PEM) which function in water retention ability, enhancing reaction kinetics, and reducing electrode CO poisoning. Hydrous membranes which rely on the water clusters in the membrane to transfer proton can be stabilized to 80-100 °C with the conductivity 10-1-10-2 S/cm when the polymers are sulfonated modified aromatics or organic-inorganic hybridized composites. Anhydrous membranes compromise the conductivity based on the proton movement under resonance structure of heterocycles, and hence can be applied in water free system. Several types of membranes with heterocyclic compounds, especially imidazoles and benzimidazoles, prepared by mixing with acids, incorporating with other thermally stable polymers, copolymerizing with other polymers (such as poly(4-vinylphosphonic aicd-co- 4-vinylimidazole), poly(4,5-vinylimidazole-co-acrylic acid)), and conjugating at polymer side chains (such as benzimidazole grafted polydimethylsiloxane, multi-benzimidazole functionalized branched polyethylenimine), are reported, and in the successful cases, the conductivities are as high as 10-2-10-5 S/cm at the temperature above 120 °C. A series of benzimidazole model compounds lead us to an understanding that proton transfer mechanism is under synergistic effects of hydrogen bond network and molecular mobility. Apart from proton conductivity, other important parameters of PEM are water uptake and swelling, gas or methanol permeability, ion exchange capacity, and single cell performance. © 2013 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.
coredata.dc:title: High temperature performance polymer electrolyte membranes
